pleasantActivities.title: Making Time for Pleasant Activities
pleasantActivities.summary: Why enjoyable activities matter for your wellbeing and how to fit them into a busy caregiving life.
pleasantActivities.content:
## The Disappearing Joy

When caregiving takes over your life, the activities that used to bring you joy are often the first things to go. The book stays unread on the nightstand. The garden grows weedy. The friends you used to meet for coffee become distant. You may not even notice it happening — until one day you realise you cannot remember the last time you did something purely for your own enjoyment.

This is not a small thing. Pleasant activities are not luxuries — they are essential fuel for your emotional and physical health. Research consistently shows that people who regularly engage in enjoyable activities have lower rates of depression, better sleep, stronger immune systems, and greater resilience in the face of stress.

## Why Pleasant Activities Disappear

Several forces push enjoyable activities out of a carer's life:

- **Time pressure.** Caregiving fills every available hour, and your own activities feel like the easiest thing to sacrifice.
- **Guilt.** Doing something enjoyable while your loved one is struggling can feel wrong. You may think you do not deserve to have fun.
- **Exhaustion.** When you finally have a free moment, you may be too tired to do anything but collapse.
- **Loss of interest.** Sustained stress can dull your ability to feel pleasure — a phenomenon psychologists call anhedonia. Things that used to excite you may feel flat.

## The Case for Bringing Them Back

Pleasant activities are not selfish. They are a form of self-care that directly benefits both you and the person you care for. When you are replenished, you are more patient, more creative, and more present. When you are depleted, everything suffers.

Think of pleasant activities as recharging a battery. You cannot run on empty indefinitely.

## Building Your Personal List

Start by making a list of activities that bring you pleasure — or that used to. Do not judge them or worry about whether they are practical right now. Just brainstorm. Here are some categories to spark ideas:

**Quick activities (5 to 15 minutes):**
- Listening to a favourite song
- Stepping outside and feeling the sun
- Reading a few pages of a book
- Doing a crossword or puzzle
- Calling or texting a friend
- Having a cup of tea in a quiet spot

**Medium activities (30 minutes to an hour):**
- Going for a walk
- Watching a favourite show
- Cooking something you enjoy
- Gardening
- Drawing, painting, or crafting
- Playing a musical instrument

**Longer activities (when respite is available):**
- Meeting a friend for coffee or lunch
- Going to a film or concert
- Visiting a place you enjoy
- Taking a class
- Having a long bath or spa treatment

## Scheduling Joy

Pleasant activities will not happen by accident — you need to schedule them deliberately, just as you schedule medical appointments and caregiving tasks.

- **Start small.** Aim for one pleasant activity per day, even if it is just five minutes. A short walk, a favourite song, a moment in the garden.
- **Put it on the calendar.** Write it down. Treat it as a non-negotiable appointment.
- **Use transition moments.** The few minutes while your loved one naps, the time after they go to bed, the gap between tasks — these are opportunities.
- **Involve your loved one when possible.** Some pleasant activities can be shared — listening to music together, looking at photographs, gentle movement.

## Overcoming Guilt

If guilt creeps in when you do something for yourself, try these reframes:

- "I am recharging so I can be a better carer."
- "My loved one would want me to have moments of joy."
- "I cannot give what I do not have."
- "Taking care of myself is taking care of our whole family."

## When Nothing Feels Enjoyable

If you have reached a point where nothing gives you pleasure, pay attention to that signal. It may mean you are experiencing depression, and that is not something to push through alone. Talk to your doctor or a counsellor. Depression is common among carers, it is treatable, and getting help is a sign of strength.

## One Activity Today

Do not wait for the perfect moment. Choose one small, pleasant activity and do it today. It does not need to be grand. It just needs to be yours.

---

cognitiveReframing.title: Thinking Differently
cognitiveReframing.summary: How changing the way you think about difficult situations can reduce stress and build resilience.
cognitiveReframing.content:
## The Power of Your Thoughts

The situations you face as a carer are often beyond your control — you cannot stop the progression of dementia, you cannot make your loved one remember, and you cannot add more hours to the day. But there is one thing you always have some control over: how you think about those situations.

This is the idea behind cognitive reframing — noticing unhelpful thought patterns and learning to see the same situation from a different, more balanced perspective. It is not about pretending everything is fine. It is about finding a way to think about difficult situations that feels more accurate and more bearable.

## How Unhelpful Thoughts Work

When you are under sustained stress, your thinking tends to become more extreme, more negative, and less accurate. You may not even notice it happening. Here are some common patterns:

- **All-or-nothing thinking.** "I'm a terrible carer" because of one bad moment, ignoring the hundreds of good things you do every day.
- **Catastrophising.** "Everything is falling apart" when one thing goes wrong.
- **Mind reading.** "Everyone thinks I'm not coping" without any evidence for that belief.
- **Should statements.** "I should be able to handle this without feeling frustrated." Says who?
- **Discounting the positive.** "The good moments don't count because the hard ones are so overwhelming."

These thought patterns are normal. Everyone has them, especially under stress. The goal is not to eliminate them but to recognise them when they appear and choose a more helpful response.

## The Reframing Process

When you notice yourself feeling overwhelmed, anxious, or hopeless, try this three-step process:

**Step 1: Catch the thought.**
Pause and ask yourself: "What am I telling myself right now?" Write it down if you can. For example: "I can't do this anymore."

**Step 2: Examine the thought.**
Ask yourself:
- Is this thought completely true, or is it an exaggeration?
- What would I say to a friend who told me they were thinking this?
- Is there another way to look at this situation?
- Am I focusing on the worst case and ignoring other possibilities?

**Step 3: Reframe the thought.**
Find a more balanced version. Not falsely positive — just more accurate. For example: "This is incredibly hard right now, and I have got through hard moments before. I need more support, and I can ask for it."

## Reframing in Practice

Here are some common caregiving thoughts and possible reframes:

| Unhelpful thought | Reframe |
|---|---|
| "I'm failing as a carer." | "I'm doing my best in an incredibly difficult situation. No one could do this perfectly." |
| "I should never lose my patience." | "I'm human. Losing patience sometimes is normal. What matters is how I recover." |
| "Nobody understands what I'm going through." | "Many people haven't experienced this. I can seek out those who have — support groups, online communities." |
| "Things will only get worse." | "The future is uncertain. I can focus on making today as good as possible." |
| "I shouldn't feel angry at my loved one." | "Feeling angry at the situation is natural. It doesn't mean I love them any less." |

## When Reframing Is Hard

Sometimes a situation is genuinely awful, and no amount of reframing makes it feel okay. That is valid. Reframing is not about toxic positivity or denying reality. It is about finding the most helpful perspective available — even if that perspective is simply: "This is really hard, and I am allowed to feel that way."

If you find that negative thoughts are constant, overwhelming, or feel impossible to shift, consider talking to a counsellor or therapist. Persistent negative thinking can be a sign of depression, which is common among carers and responds well to professional support.

## Building the Habit

Reframing gets easier with practice. Try keeping a short journal where you write down one unhelpful thought each day and one reframe. Over time, you will start to catch unhelpful thoughts earlier and shift your perspective more naturally.

You do not need to change every thought. Even catching one or two automatic negative thoughts per day and finding a more balanced view can meaningfully reduce your stress.

---

*Based on WHO iSupport for Dementia (2019), CC BY-NC-SA 3.0 IGO. Adapted for general wellness information.*

supportedDecisions.title: Supported Decision-Making
supportedDecisions.summary: How to help your loved one stay involved in choices about their own life for as long as possible.
supportedDecisions.content:
## Why Decisions Matter

One of the most difficult aspects of caring for someone with dementia is knowing when to step in and when to step back. As memory and thinking skills change, your loved one will gradually need more help with decisions — but that does not mean they should be excluded from the process.

Supported decision-making means helping your loved one make their own choices for as long as possible, rather than making decisions for them. It respects their dignity, preserves their sense of independence, and often leads to better outcomes for everyone.

## The Difference Between Supporting and Replacing

There is an important distinction between:

- **Supported decision-making:** Helping your loved one understand their options and express their preferences, so they can make their own choices with assistance.
- **Substitute decision-making:** Making decisions on their behalf because they are no longer able to participate.

In the early and middle stages, most people with dementia can still participate in many decisions — especially when the choices are presented simply and clearly. The goal is to keep them involved for as long as it is safe and practical to do so.

## Practical Strategies

**Simplify choices.** Instead of open-ended questions, offer two or three clear options. "Would you like chicken or fish tonight?" is much easier to process than "What do you want for dinner?"

**Use visual aids.** Show options rather than just describing them. Hold up two shirts. Point to items on a menu. Show photographs of places you might visit. Visual information is often easier to process than verbal information.

**Choose the right moment.** Try to have important conversations when your loved one is at their best — usually in the morning, when they are rested and alert. Avoid times when they are tired, hungry, or agitated.

**Give time to process.** After presenting options, wait patiently. It may take longer than you expect for your loved one to process the information and form a response. Resist the urge to jump in and decide for them.

**Focus on preferences, not logic.** Your loved one may not be able to weigh complex pros and cons, but they can often express what they prefer, what they enjoy, and what feels right. These preferences are valuable and should be honoured.

**Break big decisions into smaller steps.** Instead of asking about a major change all at once, address it in smaller, more manageable pieces over time.

## Areas Where Involvement Matters Most

Even as dementia progresses, try to keep your loved one involved in:

- **Daily choices:** What to wear, what to eat, what activities to do. These seem small but they preserve a sense of control.
- **Social preferences:** Who they want to spend time with, whether they want visitors, how they want to spend their day.
- **Personal care preferences:** How they like their hair, what products they prefer, their bathing routine.
- **Values and wishes:** What matters most to them in life. These conversations, held early, guide your decisions later.

## When to Step In

There are times when you will need to make decisions on your loved one's behalf — particularly around safety, health, and finances. Signs that more involvement from you is needed include:

- Decisions that put their safety at risk (wanting to drive when it is no longer safe, for example)
- Inability to understand the consequences of a choice
- Repeated decisions that cause harm or distress
- Financial decisions that could lead to exploitation

When you do need to step in, do so with compassion. Explain simply, focus on their safety and comfort, and try to honour their known preferences and values.

## Involving Others

Supported decision-making works best when the whole care team is aligned. Share your loved one's preferences with other family members and any professional carers involved. When everyone knows that your loved one likes their tea with milk, prefers to shower in the evening, and enjoys sitting in the garden after lunch, daily care becomes more respectful and more personal.

## Respecting the Person

At its heart, supported decision-making is about respecting the person behind the condition. Your loved one has a lifetime of preferences, values, and experiences that do not disappear because of dementia. By keeping them involved in choices about their own life, you honour who they are — and who they have always been.

---

behaviourChangeCycle.title: Understanding Behaviour Changes
behaviourChangeCycle.summary: A practical framework for understanding why behaviour changes happen and how to respond.
behaviourChangeCycle.content:
## Behaviour Is Communication

When someone with dementia behaves in ways that are challenging — becoming agitated, refusing care, calling out repeatedly, or acting in ways that seem out of character — it is almost always an attempt to communicate something. The person is not being difficult on purpose. Their brain has lost the ability to express needs, feelings, and discomfort in the ways it once could.

Understanding this simple truth changes everything. Instead of asking "How do I stop this behaviour?" you start asking "What is this behaviour telling me?" — and that question leads to much better answers.

## The A-B-C Framework

A helpful way to understand behaviour changes is the A-B-C approach:

- **A — Antecedent.** What happened just before the behaviour? What was the trigger? This could be something in the environment (noise, a new person), a physical need (pain, hunger, needing the bathroom), or an emotional trigger (feeling confused, lonely, or frightened).
- **B — Behaviour.** What exactly happened? Describe the behaviour without judgement. "Called out loudly for 10 minutes" is more useful than "Was being difficult."
- **C — Consequence.** What happened after the behaviour? How did people around them respond? Did the behaviour get better or worse?

By tracking A-B-C patterns over time, you often start to see connections that help you prevent or reduce challenging behaviours.

## Common Causes of Behaviour Changes

**Physical causes** should always be checked first:
- Pain — your loved one may not be able to tell you they are hurting
- Infection — urinary tract infections are a very common and often overlooked cause of sudden behaviour changes
- Constipation or other digestive discomfort
- Hunger, thirst, or fatigue
- Medication side effects
- Sensory problems — poor vision or hearing

**Environmental causes:**
- Too much noise or activity
- Unfamiliar surroundings or people
- Poor lighting
- Feeling too hot or too cold
- Lack of meaningful activity

**Emotional and psychological causes:**
- Fear or confusion
- Loneliness or boredom
- Feeling a loss of control
- Frustration at not being understood
- Grief or sadness

## Responding to Behaviour Changes

Once you start thinking of behaviour as communication, your response changes naturally:

**Stay calm.** Your emotional state directly affects your loved one's emotional state. If you become tense or frustrated, the behaviour is likely to escalate.

**Check physical needs first.** Is the person in pain? Do they need the bathroom? Are they hungry, thirsty, or tired? These basic needs are the most common triggers and the easiest to address.

**Adjust the environment.** Reduce noise, improve lighting, remove sources of confusion. Sometimes simply moving to a different room makes a significant difference.

**Validate the emotion.** "I can see you're upset" or "It sounds like something is bothering you" acknowledges the person's experience and can reduce distress.

**Redirect gently.** After acknowledging the emotion, offer a pleasant alternative — a favourite activity, a snack, a walk, or some music.

**Avoid confrontation.** Do not argue, correct, or try to reason with logic. These approaches do not work when the brain is overwhelmed and typically make things worse.

## Keeping a Behaviour Diary

A simple diary can reveal patterns you might otherwise miss. Each time a challenging behaviour occurs, note:

- The date and time
- What was happening just before (the antecedent)
- What the behaviour looked like
- What seemed to help

After a week or two, review your notes. You may discover that the behaviour always happens at the same time of day, after the same activity, or when a particular need is unmet. These patterns point directly to solutions.

## Working with Your Care Team

Share your observations with your loved one's doctor and other members of your care team. Behaviour changes can sometimes signal a medical issue that needs attention. Your detailed observations are valuable — you know your loved one better than anyone, and the patterns you notice help professionals provide better care.

---

*Based on WHO iSupport for Dementia (2019), CC BY-NC-SA 3.0 IGO. Adapted for general wellness information.*

memoryLossStrategies.title: Responding to Memory Loss
memoryLossStrategies.summary: Practical strategies for supporting someone whose short-term memory is affected.
memoryLossStrategies.content:
## Living with Memory Changes

Memory loss is often the most visible and the most heartbreaking aspect of dementia. Your loved one may ask the same question repeatedly, forget recent conversations, misplace objects, or not remember what they had for breakfast. For the person experiencing it, this can be frightening and frustrating. For you, it can be exhausting and emotionally painful.

Understanding how memory changes work — and knowing practical strategies to help — can make daily life smoother for both of you.

## What Changes and What Stays

Dementia typically affects recent memory first. Your loved one may clearly remember events from decades ago but not recall what happened an hour ago. This is because different types of memory are stored in different parts of the brain, and dementia tends to affect the areas responsible for new memories before reaching older, more deeply encoded ones.

**Often affected early:**
- Recent events and conversations
- Names of new people
- Where objects were placed
- Appointments and schedules
- What was just said or asked

**Often preserved longer:**
- Long-term memories from childhood and early adulthood
- Procedural memory (how to do familiar tasks like brushing teeth or stirring a pot)
- Emotional memory (feelings associated with people and places)
- Musical memory (familiar songs and melodies)

Understanding this pattern helps you work with your loved one's strengths rather than focusing on what they have lost.

## Practical Strategies

**Use memory aids.** External supports can compensate for what the brain can no longer do on its own:

- A whiteboard or notice board in a central location with the day, date, and any key information for the day
- Labels on drawers and cupboards showing what is inside
- A simple daily schedule posted where it can be easily seen
- A clock that shows the day of the week and whether it is morning or afternoon
- A basket by the door for keys, wallet, and glasses — always the same place

**Establish routines.** When the same things happen in the same order every day, the brain can rely on procedural memory rather than having to remember new information each time. Consistent routines for meals, bathing, and activities reduce confusion and increase confidence.

**Keep communication clear.** When giving information:
- Say it simply and in short sentences
- Give one piece of information at a time
- Use the person's name to get their attention first
- Avoid saying "Don't you remember?" — this question highlights the failure and causes distress

**Respond to repeated questions with patience.** Remember that each time your loved one asks, it is genuinely the first time for them. Respond as warmly as you can. If the same question keeps coming, the underlying emotion — usually anxiety — may be what needs addressing rather than the factual answer.

**Help with object finding.** Misplacing objects is one of the most common and most frustrating consequences of memory loss:
- Designate specific places for important items and always return them there
- Keep spare sets of frequently lost items like glasses and keys
- Check bins and unusual locations — people with memory changes sometimes put things in unexpected places
- Try not to get frustrated. This happens because of the brain changes, not carelessness

**Use photographs and familiar objects.** Photos, favourite belongings, and familiar music can trigger positive memories and provide comfort. A photo wall, a memory box, or a playlist of beloved songs can be grounding anchors in the day.

## Supporting Emotional Wellbeing

Memory loss can make your loved one feel anxious, embarrassed, or frightened. You can help by:

- **Not testing or quizzing them.** Avoid asking "Do you know who this is?" or "What did we do yesterday?" These questions set them up to fail.
- **Joining their reality.** If they believe it is 1975 or that they are going to work tomorrow, gently engage with their experience rather than correcting them.
- **Focusing on feelings, not facts.** Even when the details are wrong, the emotions are real. Respond to the feeling.
- **Celebrating what they can still do.** Notice and appreciate their strengths — the song they can still sing, the skill they still have, the smile they still share.

## Taking Care of Yourself

Watching someone you love lose their memory is one of the most painful experiences there is. Give yourself permission to grieve, to feel frustrated, and to have hard days. Connect with others who understand — other carers, a support group, a counsellor. You are not alone in this, even when it feels that way.

---

*Based on WHO iSupport for Dementia (2019), CC BY-NC-SA 3.0 IGO. Adapted for general wellness information.*

managingAggression.title: Managing Aggression Safely
managingAggression.summary: Understanding what drives aggressive behaviour and how to respond safely and compassionately.
managingAggression.content:
## When Your Loved One Becomes Aggressive

Aggression — whether verbal (shouting, swearing, threatening) or physical (hitting, pushing, grabbing, throwing objects) — is one of the most distressing aspects of dementia care. If your loved one has become aggressive, you may feel shocked, hurt, frightened, or deeply sad. These reactions are completely natural.

The most important thing to understand is that aggression in dementia is not deliberate. It is not a choice. Your loved one is not trying to hurt you. Their brain has lost the ability to manage frustration, fear, and confusion in the ways it once could, and aggression is often the only way left to express overwhelming distress.

## Why Aggression Happens

Aggression is almost always triggered by something — even if the cause is not immediately obvious:

- **Pain or physical discomfort.** This is the single most common cause. Your loved one may not be able to tell you they are hurting. Dental pain, constipation, infections, arthritis, and ill-fitting clothing are all common culprits.
- **Fear and confusion.** Imagine being approached by someone you do not recognise, who begins undressing you. For someone with dementia, this can be the reality of personal care. Fear triggers a fight-or-flight response.
- **Feeling overwhelmed.** Too much noise, too many people, too many demands, or a task that feels too complicated.
- **Loss of control.** Being told what to do, having choices taken away, or feeling powerless.
- **Frustration.** Not being able to communicate, not being understood, or not being able to do something that used to be easy.
- **Medication effects.** Some medications can increase agitation or cause confusion.

## How to Respond in the Moment

**Your safety comes first.** If you feel physically threatened, step back. Move out of reach. Leave the room if you need to. You cannot help your loved one if you are hurt.

**Stay as calm as possible.** Speak in a low, gentle voice. Avoid raising your voice or moving suddenly. Your calm presence is the most powerful tool you have.

**Do not argue or confront.** Resist the urge to reason, correct, or say "Stop that." These responses escalate the situation.

**Give space.** Step back physically. Sometimes the best thing you can do is create distance and wait. Many episodes pass within a few minutes if the person is not further provoked.

**Validate the emotion.** "I can see you're really upset. I'm sorry this is hard." Even if the words are not fully understood, the tone communicates safety and empathy.

**Look for the trigger.** Can you identify what started the episode? If so, try to address it. If personal care was the trigger, stop and try again later. If noise was the trigger, reduce it.

**Distract and redirect.** Once the intensity begins to decrease, gently offer something pleasant — a favourite snack, music, a change of scenery.

## Prevention Strategies

**Address pain proactively.** If you suspect your loved one may be in pain, talk to their doctor. Sometimes a trial of simple pain relief reveals that pain was driving the behaviour.

**Approach personal care gently.** Explain each step before you do it: "I'm going to help you put your shirt on now." Use a calm, warm voice. Cover what you can to preserve dignity.

**Give choices.** "Would you like to wash your face first or your hands?" gives a sense of control.

**Watch for patterns.** Keep a note of when aggression happens — time of day, activity, who was present, what happened beforehand. Patterns help you anticipate and prevent.

**Simplify the environment.** Reduce noise, improve lighting, and create calm spaces. A predictable, soothing environment reduces triggers.

**Review medications.** Ask the doctor whether any current medications could be contributing to agitation.

## Taking Care of Yourself After an Episode

Being on the receiving end of aggression from someone you love is painful — physically and emotionally. After an episode:

- **Give yourself time to recover.** You may feel shaky, tearful, or angry. These reactions are normal.
- **Do not blame yourself.** You did not cause this. The disease caused this.
- **Talk to someone.** A friend, a support group, a counsellor. Do not carry this alone.
- **Assess whether you need more help.** If aggression is frequent or escalating, talk to the doctor. Additional support — whether through medication adjustments, professional carers, or changes to the care environment — may be needed.

## When to Seek Professional Help

Contact the doctor if:
- Aggression is new or suddenly worse (this may indicate pain, infection, or medication issues)
- You or others are being hurt
- You feel unsafe
- The behaviour is not responding to your usual strategies

You are not failing by asking for help. You are doing what any good carer would do — making sure everyone is safe.

---

depressionAnxietyApathy.title: Depression, Anxiety and Apathy
depressionAnxietyApathy.summary: Recognising and responding to common mood changes in someone with dementia.
depressionAnxietyApathy.content:
## More Than Just Memory

Dementia affects far more than memory. Many people with dementia also experience significant changes in mood and motivation. Depression, anxiety, and apathy are among the most common of these changes, and they can have a profound impact on daily life and quality of wellbeing.

Recognising these changes is the first step toward helping. Often, mood changes are treatable or can be significantly improved with the right support.

## Depression

Depression is common in dementia, particularly in the early and middle stages. Your loved one may be aware of their declining abilities, grieving the loss of their former self, and struggling with a world that feels increasingly confusing.

**Signs to watch for:**
- Persistent sadness, tearfulness, or a flat expression
- Loss of interest in activities they used to enjoy
- Changes in appetite — eating much more or much less than usual
- Sleep changes — sleeping too much or having trouble sleeping
- Withdrawing from social contact
- Expressing feelings of worthlessness or being a burden
- Increased irritability or restlessness

**How to help:**
- **Maintain a daily routine** with regular activities, meals, and social contact. Structure provides a sense of safety and purpose.
- **Encourage gentle physical activity.** Even a short walk or gentle stretching can lift mood. The key is to make it enjoyable, not forced.
- **Stay socially connected.** Visit with family and friends, attend familiar community activities, or simply spend quality time together.
- **Listen and validate.** If your loved one expresses sadness, resist the urge to cheer them up. Instead, say something like: "That sounds really hard. I'm here with you." Feeling heard is more comforting than being told to look on the bright side.
- **Talk to the doctor.** Depression in dementia can sometimes be helped with changes in routine, increased activity, or in some cases, medication. It is always worth discussing.

## Anxiety

Anxiety often shows up as restlessness, constant worry, repeated questioning, clinging to a familiar person, or resistance to new situations. Your loved one may not use the word "anxious" — but their behaviour tells you they are feeling unsafe.

**Signs to watch for:**
- Excessive worry or fearfulness
- Restlessness or inability to settle
- Asking the same question over and over (often anxiety-driven)
- Resistance to being left alone
- Tension, trembling, or rapid breathing
- Avoidance of activities or places

**How to help:**
- **Create predictability.** Anxiety thrives on uncertainty. A consistent routine, familiar surroundings, and clear, simple communication all reduce anxiety.
- **Offer reassurance through presence.** Sometimes just being nearby — visible and calm — is the most effective remedy. Your calm presence communicates safety.
- **Reduce overwhelm.** Simplify the environment. Fewer choices, less noise, fewer people at once. When the world feels smaller and more manageable, anxiety decreases.
- **Use gentle touch.** A hand on the arm, holding hands, or a warm embrace can communicate safety more effectively than words.
- **Distract with pleasant activities.** When anxiety is building, a change of activity or scenery can break the cycle. Music is particularly effective.

## Apathy

Apathy is one of the most common behavioural changes in dementia and one of the most misunderstood. It looks like laziness or stubbornness, but it is neither. Apathy is caused by damage to the parts of the brain responsible for motivation and initiative.

A person with apathy is not choosing to do nothing. Their brain is no longer generating the internal drive to start activities, even ones they used to enjoy.

**Signs to watch for:**
- Loss of interest in hobbies, socialising, or daily activities
- Sitting passively for long periods without seeming bored
- Reduced emotional response — not seeming to care about things that used to matter
- Needing prompting to start any activity
- Withdrawal from conversations

**How to help:**
- **Gently initiate activities.** Your loved one may not be able to start an activity on their own, but they may engage once someone else gets it going. "Let's look at these photographs together" is more effective than "Do you want to look at photographs?"
- **Keep activities simple and enjoyable.** Activities that tap into long-standing interests or procedural memory (like folding laundry, gardening, or listening to familiar music) are most likely to spark engagement.
- **Accept partial participation.** If your loved one engages for five minutes and then stops, that is a success. Do not push for more.
- **Avoid taking it personally.** Apathy is not rejection of you or of life. It is a brain change that reduces the internal engine of motivation.
- **Maintain routine.** Even when your loved one does not seem interested, a structured day with gentle activity is better for their wellbeing than endless sitting.

## When to Talk to the Doctor

Always mention mood changes to your loved one's doctor. Depression, anxiety, and apathy can sometimes be improved with changes in routine, increased activity, social engagement, or in some cases, medication. Ruling out other causes — such as pain, infection, or medication side effects — is also important.

You know your loved one best. Trust your observations and share them.

---

delusionsHallucinations.title: Delusions and Hallucinations
delusionsHallucinations.summary: What to do when your loved one sees, hears, or believes things that are not there.
delusionsHallucinations.content:
## When Reality Shifts

One of the more frightening aspects of dementia — for both the person experiencing it and the carer — is when your loved one begins seeing, hearing, or believing things that are not real. These experiences can be deeply distressing, and knowing how to respond makes an enormous difference.

## Understanding the Difference

**Hallucinations** are sensory experiences that feel completely real to the person but have no external source. Visual hallucinations are the most common — seeing people, animals, or objects that are not there. Auditory hallucinations (hearing voices or sounds) and other sensory hallucinations (feeling touch, smelling things) can also occur.

**Delusions** are firmly held beliefs that are not based in reality. Common examples include:
- Believing someone is stealing from them
- Believing their spouse is an imposter
- Believing people on television are in the room
- Believing someone is coming to harm them
- Believing they need to go to a job or school they left decades ago

Hallucinations and delusions are more common in certain types of dementia, particularly Lewy body dementia, but they can occur in any form.

## Why They Happen

- **Brain changes.** Dementia damages the brain's ability to process sensory information correctly and to distinguish between real and imagined experiences.
- **Poor lighting.** Shadows, reflections, and dim lighting can trick a brain that is already struggling to interpret visual information.
- **Medications.** Some medications can cause or worsen hallucinations. Always report new hallucinations to the doctor.
- **Infections.** A sudden onset of hallucinations or delusions can signal an infection, especially a urinary tract infection.
- **Sensory impairment.** Poor vision or hearing increases the brain's tendency to "fill in" missing information, sometimes inaccurately.

## How to Respond

**Do not argue.** The experience is completely real to your loved one. Telling them "That's not real" or "You're imagining things" will not convince them — it will only make them feel dismissed, confused, or frightened.

**Stay calm and reassuring.** "I can see you're worried. I'm right here with you. You're safe." Your calm presence is often the most effective intervention.

**Acknowledge what they are experiencing.** "I can see that's upsetting you" validates their emotional experience without confirming or denying the content.

**Check the environment.** Is there a shadow that could look like a person? A reflection in a mirror or window? A noise from outside that could be misinterpreted? Sometimes simple environmental changes can reduce hallucinations.

**Distract gently.** Once you have acknowledged their feelings, try redirecting to a pleasant activity. "Let's go make some tea" or "Come sit with me — I want to show you something" can shift their attention.

**Do not take accusations personally.** If your loved one accuses you of stealing or being an imposter, it is not a reflection of their true feelings about you. It is the disease distorting their perception. This is incredibly painful, but try to respond to the fear underneath the accusation rather than the accusation itself.

## When Hallucinations Are Not Distressing

Not all hallucinations cause distress. Some people with dementia see children playing, a beloved pet, or a deceased family member and find the experience comforting. If the hallucination is pleasant and not causing anxiety or dangerous behaviour, there may be no need to intervene. Simply be present and let your loved one enjoy the experience.

## Reducing the Risk

- **Improve lighting.** Well-lit rooms with minimal shadows reduce visual misinterpretation. Night lights in hallways and bathrooms are especially important.
- **Reduce mirrors.** Reflections can be confusing and frightening — especially if your loved one does not recognise their own reflection.
- **Keep the environment simple.** Clutter, busy patterns, and a television left on can all contribute to confusion.
- **Maintain a regular routine.** Predictability reduces anxiety, which can trigger or worsen hallucinations and delusions.
- **Ensure glasses and hearing aids are clean and working.** Supporting accurate sensory input reduces the brain's tendency to fill in gaps.

## When to Seek Medical Help

Contact the doctor if:
- Hallucinations or delusions are new or suddenly worse
- They cause significant distress or dangerous behaviour
- You suspect a medication may be the cause
- There are other new symptoms (fever, confusion, pain) that could suggest infection

There are ways to help, and you do not have to navigate this alone.

---

*Based on WHO iSupport for Dementia (2019), CC BY-NC-SA 3.0 IGO. Adapted for general wellness information.*

eatingDrinkingHealth.title: Eating, Drinking and Health
eatingDrinkingHealth.summary: Supporting nutrition, hydration, and overall physical health as needs change over time.
eatingDrinkingHealth.content:
## Why Nutrition and Hydration Matter

Good nutrition and adequate hydration are essential for everyone, but they become especially important — and often more challenging — when someone has dementia. Poor nutrition can worsen confusion, increase fall risk, reduce immunity, and accelerate physical decline. Dehydration can cause or mimic many of the most distressing symptoms of dementia, including increased confusion, agitation, and urinary tract infections.

The good news is that with some practical adjustments, you can help your loved one eat and drink well throughout the course of the condition.

## How Dementia Affects Eating and Drinking

As dementia progresses, your loved one may experience:

- **Forgetting to eat or drink.** They may simply not remember their last meal or not feel hunger or thirst signals as strongly.
- **Difficulty using utensils.** The coordination required to use a knife and fork may become challenging.
- **Problems with chewing and swallowing.** Oral muscles may weaken, and the brain may have difficulty coordinating the complex sequence of chewing and swallowing.
- **Changes in taste and smell.** Food may not taste or smell as it once did, which can reduce appetite.
- **Difficulty recognising food.** In later stages, your loved one may not recognise items on a plate as food.
- **Distraction during meals.** A busy environment can make it hard to focus on eating.

## Practical Strategies for Better Nutrition

**Make meals social.** Eating together is one of the most effective ways to encourage good nutrition. Your loved one is more likely to eat when they see you eating. Conversation and company make meals more enjoyable.

**Serve smaller, more frequent meals.** Five or six smaller meals or snacks throughout the day may work better than three large ones, especially if attention span or appetite is reduced.

**Focus on nutrient-rich foods.** When overall intake is reduced, every bite matters. Choose foods that are rich in calories and nutrients: eggs, cheese, nut butters, avocado, yoghurt, and fortified cereals.

**Offer finger foods.** When utensils become difficult, finger foods preserve independence and dignity. Sandwiches, fruit pieces, cheese cubes, steamed vegetable sticks, meatballs, and fish fingers are all easy to eat by hand.

**Use contrasting colours.** Serve food on a plain plate that contrasts with the food colour. White rice on a white plate is invisible; the same rice on a dark blue plate is easy to see.

**Minimise distractions.** Turn off the television, clear unnecessary items from the table, and keep the environment calm during meals.

**Be patient.** Meals may take longer than they used to. Allow plenty of time, and resist the urge to rush.

## Keeping Hydration Up

Dehydration is a serious and common problem. Your loved one may not feel thirsty or may forget to drink.

- **Offer drinks regularly** throughout the day — do not wait for them to ask.
- **Use clear, coloured cups** that are easy to hold and easy to see.
- **Try different options.** Water, fruit juice, smoothies, herbal tea, broths, and foods with high water content (like watermelon, cucumber, and soup) all contribute to hydration.
- **Keep a drink within reach** at all times — on the bedside table, by their favourite chair, and at the dining table.
- **Track intake** if you are concerned. A simple tally of cups offered and consumed can help you spot problems early.

## Managing Swallowing Difficulties

If your loved one coughs during meals, takes a long time to swallow, or seems to have food sticking in their throat, talk to the doctor. Swallowing difficulties (dysphagia) are common in the later stages and can lead to choking or aspiration.

A speech and language therapist can assess swallowing and recommend:
- Changes in food texture (softer foods, pureed foods)
- Changes in drink consistency (thickened liquids)
- Positioning strategies (sitting upright, chin tuck)
- Safe eating techniques

## General Health Matters

Beyond nutrition, maintaining your loved one's general health helps support their quality of life:

- **Keep up with regular health check-ups** including dental visits, eye exams, and hearing tests.
- **Monitor weight.** Unexplained weight loss can signal that nutrition needs attention or that there is an underlying health issue.
- **Stay active.** Gentle daily movement supports appetite, digestion, sleep, and mood.
- **Review medications regularly** with the doctor to check for side effects that may affect appetite or digestion.

## When to Talk to the Doctor

Consult the doctor if:
- Your loved one is losing weight unintentionally
- They are refusing food or drink consistently
- You notice coughing, choking, or difficulty swallowing
- There are sudden changes in appetite or eating behaviour

Good nutrition and hydration are among the most practical and impactful things you can support. Small changes can make a real difference.

---

*Based on WHO iSupport for Dementia (2019), CC BY-NC-SA 3.0 IGO. Adapted for general wellness information.*

toiletingContinence.title: Toileting and Continence Care
toiletingContinence.summary: Sensitive, practical guidance for managing one of caregiving's most personal challenges.
toiletingContinence.content:
## A Sensitive Topic

Toileting and continence are among the most personal and potentially embarrassing aspects of care — for your loved one and for you. Many carers find this the hardest adjustment to make. If you are struggling with this, you are not alone, and there is no shame in finding it difficult.

Understanding why continence problems happen and knowing practical strategies to manage them can reduce stress for everyone and help preserve your loved one's dignity.

## Why Continence Changes Happen

Dementia can affect continence in several ways:

- **Forgetting where the bathroom is.** Your loved one may not remember the location of the toilet, especially in unfamiliar settings.
- **Not recognising the need.** The brain may not process the body's signals of a full bladder or bowel in time.
- **Difficulty with clothing.** Buttons, zips, and belts can become impossible to manage quickly enough.
- **Communication difficulties.** Your loved one may not be able to tell you they need the bathroom.
- **Mobility issues.** Getting to the bathroom in time may be physically difficult.
- **Medical causes.** Urinary tract infections, prostate problems, constipation, and certain medications can all affect continence.

It is important to know that incontinence is not inevitable and that many causes are treatable. Always discuss continence changes with the doctor.

## Practical Strategies

**Establish a toileting routine.** Rather than waiting for your loved one to ask, offer regular bathroom trips — for example, first thing in the morning, after meals, and before bed. A consistent schedule can prevent many accidents.

**Make the bathroom easy to find.** Leave the bathroom door open with the light on. Place a sign or picture on the door. Use a coloured toilet seat that contrasts with the floor and walls. At night, use a night light to illuminate the path.

**Simplify clothing.** Replace buttons and zips with elastic waistbands and velcro closures. Clothing that is easy to pull down quickly makes a significant difference.

**Watch for cues.** Your loved one may not be able to say they need the bathroom, but they may show signs — restlessness, pulling at clothing, a particular facial expression, or heading toward a specific area. Learn to recognise these signals.

**Reduce fluid intake before bed** — but make sure total daily intake stays adequate. Offer most drinks during the morning and early afternoon.

**Have supplies ready.** Keep a change of clothes, wipes, and a plastic bag in the bathroom and in your bag when you go out. Being prepared reduces panic if accidents happen.

## When Accidents Happen

Accidents will happen. How you respond makes an enormous difference to your loved one's emotional wellbeing.

- **Stay calm and matter-of-fact.** Your loved one will pick up on your reaction. A neutral, gentle tone communicates that this is not a disaster.
- **Never scold or express frustration.** Your loved one did not do this on purpose. Shame and embarrassment can increase anxiety, which makes continence worse.
- **Clean up quietly and efficiently.** Treat it as a routine matter. "Let's get you freshened up" is all you need to say.
- **Protect their dignity.** Close the door. Cover them while you help. Speak to them, not about them.

## Using Continence Products

There is a wide range of continence products available — from light pads to full protective underwear. Using them is not a sign of failure. It is a practical solution that protects clothing, furniture, and your loved one's confidence.

**Tips for choosing products:**
- Start with the lightest protection needed and adjust as required
- Choose products that look and feel as much like regular underwear as possible
- Make sure they fit well — too large and they leak, too small and they are uncomfortable
- Many products are very discreet and cannot be seen under clothing

Avoid using the word "nappy" or "diaper" — these are adult protective products, and the language matters for dignity.

## Skin Care

Moisture from incontinence can irritate skin and lead to painful rashes. Protect your loved one's skin by:

- Changing wet or soiled products promptly
- Cleaning gently with warm water and a soft cloth or purpose-made wipes
- Applying a barrier cream to protect the skin
- Allowing the skin to air-dry when possible
- Checking the skin regularly for redness or irritation

## Looking After Yourself

Managing someone else's continence is emotionally and physically demanding. It is okay to find it hard. It is okay to feel uncomfortable. And it is okay to ask for help — whether from family members, home care aides, or your loved one's healthcare team.

You are doing something profoundly caring by helping with this most personal aspect of daily life. Your gentleness and respect make all the difference.

---

*Based on WHO iSupport for Dementia (2019), CC BY-NC-SA 3.0 IGO. Adapted for general wellness information.*

enjoyableDay.title: Planning an Enjoyable Day
enjoyableDay.summary: How to structure each day with meaningful activities that bring comfort, purpose, and connection.
enjoyableDay.content:
## Beyond Keeping Busy

Filling the day with activities is not enough — what matters is that the activities are meaningful, enjoyable, and matched to your loved one's current abilities. An enjoyable day is not about productivity. It is about moments of connection, purpose, and pleasure.

People with dementia still need to feel useful, valued, and engaged. When the day has a gentle rhythm of meaningful activity, rest, and social contact, everyone benefits — your loved one feels calmer and more content, and your caregiving becomes smoother.

## Principles of a Good Day

**Match activities to current abilities.** An activity that was enjoyable six months ago might be frustrating now if abilities have changed. Adjust complexity downward as needed, but do not remove activities entirely — simplify them instead.

**Follow interests and history.** What did your loved one enjoy before dementia? A keen gardener may still find pleasure in potting plants. A music lover may light up when their favourite songs play. A former baker may enjoy stirring a bowl or kneading dough. Tap into lifelong interests.

**Balance activity and rest.** Too much stimulation leads to fatigue and agitation. Too little leads to boredom and restlessness. Aim for a rhythm that alternates between gentle activity and quiet time.

**Prioritise social connection.** Human contact is a fundamental need. Even brief interactions — a shared cup of tea, a short visit, a phone call — contribute to wellbeing.

**Embrace the moment.** The goal is not to complete an activity perfectly. It is to enjoy the process. If your loved one spends ten minutes arranging flowers and then loses interest, that is ten good minutes.

## Building a Daily Rhythm

A predictable structure provides comfort while allowing flexibility. Here is a framework you can adapt:

**Morning — Highest Energy:**
- Familiar morning routine (bathroom, dressing, breakfast)
- The most engaging activity of the day (a walk, a creative activity, a visit)
- A small productive task (folding laundry, watering plants, setting the table)

**Midday — Moderate Energy:**
- Lunch together
- A quieter activity (looking at photographs, listening to music, gentle conversation)
- A short rest if needed

**Afternoon — Lower Energy:**
- A light snack
- A sensory activity (hand massage, aromatherapy, sitting in the garden)
- Social time (a visitor, a phone call)

**Evening — Wind Down:**
- Dinner at a consistent time
- A calming routine (favourite television programme, gentle music, a warm drink)
- Predictable bedtime sequence

## Activity Ideas by Type

**Physical:** Walking (indoors or outdoors), gentle stretching, chair exercises, dancing to music, balloon tossing, gardening.

**Creative:** Painting or colouring, arranging flowers, simple crafts, playing a musical instrument, singing.

**Social:** Visits from family and friends, looking at photos together, sharing stories, playing simple card or board games.

**Sensory:** Listening to music, hand massage with scented lotion, feeling different textures, watching nature, aromatherapy.

**Purposeful:** Folding towels, sorting objects by colour or size, wiping surfaces, watering plants, helping prepare food.

## Tips for Success

- **Start the activity yourself** and then invite participation. "I'm going to sort these buttons — would you like to help?" works better than asking someone to start from scratch.
- **Do not correct or critique.** If the towels are folded imperfectly, that is absolutely fine. The point is participation, not perfection.
- **Offer encouragement.** "You're doing a great job" and "This is lovely" go a long way.
- **Have a Plan B.** If an activity is not working, switch to something else without making a fuss. Flexibility is key.
- **Include everyday moments.** Watching birds through the window, stroking a pet, smelling fresh bread — these ordinary moments are activities too.

## When Motivation Is Low

If your loved one seems uninterested in activities, do not take it personally. Apathy is a common feature of dementia — it is caused by brain changes, not by a lack of affection or willpower. Gently initiate activities rather than asking if they want to participate. Often, once started, engagement follows.

## Making Every Day Matter

An enjoyable day does not need to be extraordinary. It needs to include moments of warmth, connection, and purpose — however small. Some of the most meaningful moments happen in the most ordinary settings: a shared smile over breakfast, a song sung together, a hand held in comfortable silence.

---

*Based on WHO iSupport for Dementia (2019), CC BY-NC-SA 3.0 IGO. Adapted for general wellness information.*

changesInJudgement.title: Changes in Judgement
changesInJudgement.summary: Understanding how dementia affects decision-making and how to keep your loved one safe.
changesInJudgement.content:
## When Good Judgement Fades

One of the less visible but very significant effects of dementia is the gradual loss of good judgement. Your loved one may begin making decisions that seem out of character — giving money to strangers, wearing inappropriate clothing for the weather, leaving the stove on, driving unsafely, or falling for obvious scams.

These changes happen because dementia damages the parts of the brain responsible for reasoning, weighing consequences, and understanding risk. Your loved one is not being careless or stubborn — their brain is no longer able to process information the way it once could.

## How Judgement Changes Appear

Changes in judgement can affect many areas of daily life:

- **Financial decisions.** Making unusual purchases, giving money away, falling for telephone scams, forgetting to pay bills, or paying the same bill multiple times.
- **Personal safety.** Going outside in cold weather without a coat, using kitchen appliances unsafely, not recognising dangerous situations.
- **Driving.** Getting lost on familiar routes, running stop signs, reacting too slowly, making poor lane decisions. Driving requires complex, rapid judgement calls, and it is often one of the first areas where safety becomes a concern.
- **Social situations.** Saying inappropriate things, approaching strangers too familiarly, or being unable to read social cues.
- **Self-care.** Not recognising when they are ill, not understanding the importance of medications, or making poor dietary choices.

## Financial Protection

Financial vulnerability is one of the most serious consequences of impaired judgement. People with dementia are specifically targeted by scammers because they may be trusting, confused, and unable to remember previous interactions.

**Steps to protect your loved one:**
- Set up automatic payments for essential bills to prevent missed or duplicate payments
- Monitor bank accounts and credit cards regularly for unusual activity
- Consider removing or reducing credit card limits
- Register for the telephone preference service to reduce sales calls
- Discuss financial power of attorney early — it is much easier to set up while your loved one can still participate in the decision
- Keep only a small amount of cash available for daily use
- Alert the bank to the situation — many banks have protocols for vulnerable customers

## Driving Safety

Giving up driving is one of the most emotionally charged topics in dementia care. Driving represents independence, and losing it feels like losing freedom. But unsafe driving puts your loved one and others at serious risk.

**Signs that driving may no longer be safe:**
- Getting lost on familiar routes
- Near misses or minor accidents
- Driving too slowly or too fast
- Failing to observe traffic signals
- Other drivers honking frequently
- Dents or scrapes on the car that cannot be explained

**How to approach it:**
- Start the conversation early, when your loved one can still participate in planning.
- Focus on safety, not ability: "I'm worried about other drivers on the road — they drive so fast now."
- Offer alternatives: arrange for transport, set up ride services, organise a rota of friends and family who can drive.
- If your loved one refuses to stop and you believe it is unsafe, speak to their doctor. A medical recommendation to stop driving can remove you from the difficult position of being the one to say no.

## Everyday Safety

As judgement declines, everyday situations can become hazardous:

- **Kitchen safety.** Consider stove knob covers or an automatic shut-off device. Remove sharp knives from easy access. Check that the oven and hob are off after use.
- **Medication management.** Use a pre-filled pill organiser. Do not rely on your loved one to manage their own medications.
- **Door-to-door sales and phone scams.** Place a sign on the door discouraging cold callers. Register to block nuisance calls. If possible, screen phone calls.
- **Weather-appropriate clothing.** Lay out appropriate clothing each day so the choice is already made.

## Balancing Safety and Independence

This is perhaps the greatest challenge in dementia care: keeping your loved one safe while respecting their dignity and independence. Nobody wants to feel controlled, and removing freedoms can cause real distress.

**Principles that help:**
- **Involve your loved one in decisions** as much as possible, especially in the early stages.
- **Focus on what they can still do,** not just on what has become unsafe.
- **Make safety measures invisible** where possible — automatic stove shut-offs, background bank monitoring, and discreet GPS tracking are less intrusive than overt restrictions.
- **Explain changes in terms of care, not control.** "I'm going to manage the bills because I want to make sure everything stays on track" feels different from "You can't be trusted with money."
- **Expect resistance** and respond with patience. Loss of judgement often means your loved one does not recognise that their judgement has changed.

## When to Seek Professional Guidance

If you are unsure whether your loved one is safe in a particular area — driving, finances, living independently — seek a professional assessment. Occupational therapists, driving assessors, and social workers can provide objective evaluations that help guide your decisions.

You are not overreacting by being concerned. Protecting someone you love from the consequences of impaired judgement is one of the most important things you can do.

---

fallPrevention.title: Reducing Fall Risks
fallPrevention.summary: Simple changes that make home safer and reduce the chance of a serious fall.
fallPrevention.content:
## Why Falls Are a Serious Concern

Falls are one of the leading causes of injury for older adults, and the risk is significantly higher for people with dementia. Changes in balance, depth perception, judgment, and reaction time all contribute to an increased likelihood of falling. A fall can lead to serious injuries like hip fractures, head injuries, and a loss of confidence that further reduces mobility.

The encouraging news is that many falls are preventable. Simple changes to the home environment, along with attention to physical health, can significantly reduce the risk.

## Understanding Why Falls Happen

People with dementia are more likely to fall because of:

- **Balance and coordination changes.** The brain areas that control balance and movement can be affected by dementia.
- **Depth perception problems.** Your loved one may misjudge distances, not see steps clearly, or have difficulty distinguishing between surfaces of different heights.
- **Medication side effects.** Many medications — including some used for sleep, anxiety, and blood pressure — can cause dizziness, drowsiness, or unsteadiness.
- **Vision changes.** Reduced vision, especially in low light, makes it harder to see obstacles.
- **Rushing.** Trying to move quickly — especially to the bathroom — increases fall risk.
- **Inappropriate footwear.** Loose slippers, socks without grips, and shoes with slick soles all contribute to falls.
- **Environmental hazards.** Clutter, loose rugs, poor lighting, and wet floors are all common culprits.

## Home Modifications

**Flooring and rugs:**
- Remove throw rugs entirely, or secure them with non-slip backing and tape.
- Clean up spills immediately.
- Use non-slip mats in the bathroom and kitchen.
- If possible, ensure flooring is consistent in color and texture. Transitions between different floor types can be confusing.

**Lighting:**
- Install bright lighting throughout the home, especially in hallways, stairs, and the bathroom.
- Use night lights that turn on automatically at dusk in bedrooms, hallways, and bathrooms.
- Keep a flashlight by the bed in case of power outages.
- Ensure light switches are easy to find — consider illuminated switch plates.

**Stairs:**
- Install sturdy handrails on both sides of every staircase.
- Apply contrasting tape to the edge of each step to make them more visible.
- Make sure stairs are well-lit from top to bottom.
- Consider a stair gate if your loved one should not be using stairs unsupervised.

**Bathroom:**
- Install grab bars near the toilet and in the shower or tub.
- Use a non-slip mat inside the tub or shower.
- Consider a shower seat or bench.
- Use a raised toilet seat if standing up from the toilet is difficult.
- Keep the floor dry — wipe up water promptly.

**Furniture arrangement:**
- Create clear, wide pathways through every room.
- Remove low furniture like coffee tables and ottomans that can be tripped over.
- Make sure chairs and sofas are firm and at a height that makes it easy to sit down and stand up. Chairs with armrests provide extra support.
- Secure any furniture that could tip over if leaned on.

## Footwear

What your loved one wears on their feet matters enormously:

- **Choose well-fitting, supportive shoes** with non-slip soles. Shoes that fasten with velcro are easier to put on and stay more secure than slip-ons.
- **Avoid bare feet and socks on hard floors.** Both are slippery.
- **Replace worn-out shoes** that have lost their tread.
- **Avoid high heels, flip-flops, and loose slippers.**

## Physical Health and Strength

- **Encourage regular gentle exercise.** Walking, chair exercises, and gentle stretching help maintain strength and balance. Even small amounts of movement make a difference.
- **Have vision checked regularly.** Make sure any glasses prescriptions are up to date.
- **Review medications with the doctor.** Ask specifically about medications that might cause dizziness or drowsiness. Sometimes adjustments can reduce fall risk.
- **Stay hydrated.** Dehydration can cause dizziness and confusion, increasing fall risk.
- **Address foot problems.** Painful feet lead to unsteady walking. Keep toenails trimmed and address any foot issues with a podiatrist.

## What to Do After a Fall

If your loved one falls:

- **Stay calm.** Assess the situation before moving them.
- **Check for injuries.** Look for pain, swelling, or inability to move a limb. If there is any possibility of a head injury or broken bone, call emergency services.
- **Help them up carefully** if there are no serious injuries. Roll them onto their side, help them get to their knees, and then use a sturdy chair for support as they stand. Do not try to lift them alone if they are heavy or you are unsure.
- **Report the fall to their doctor,** even if there are no obvious injuries. Falls can sometimes cause internal injuries that are not immediately apparent.
- **Document what happened.** Note when and where the fall occurred, what your loved one was doing, and what the conditions were. This information helps identify patterns and prevent future falls.

## After a Fall: Preventing the Next One

Every fall is an opportunity to improve safety:

- Investigate what caused the fall and address it.
- Check if any new hazards have appeared in the home.
- Consider whether your loved one's abilities have changed and whether additional supports are needed.
- Talk to the doctor about a fall risk assessment.

Falls are common, but they are not inevitable. Each change you make — removing a rug, adding a grab bar, improving lighting — reduces the risk and helps keep your loved one safe at home longer.
